config.question: What recent experience of African Americans principally contributed to their collective surge in the 1950s to begin challenging racial segregation in America?

choices.content: their participation in World War II, both on the home front and in the armed forces
the popularity of African American art forms, such as jazz in the South, that led to increased acceptance of integrated social venues
the economic gains they had made during the Great Depression
their larger-than-ever membership numbers, including leadership roles, in America’s trade unions and political parties

answer_3.response: Consider This: The “questioning of American life” as seen in the beatnik culture was a theme also evident in race relations in the 1950s, where the white majority continued to deny basic rights to the black minority. In the Cold War period, the contradiction between denouncing the Soviet Union for its human rights violations and the second-class status of African Americans began to arouse the national conscience. See L.O. 29.3 The Struggle over Civil Rights.
